solutionExplanation: 'All clues point to the Eiffel Tower: a structure built as a temporary experiment, later preserved for its height and engineering design, and located on the Champ de Mars in Paris.'
hint1: 'I was meant to be temporary - my survival was never guaranteed.'
hint1Explanation: The Eiffel Tower was built for the 1889 World's Fair and was originally planned to be dismantled after 20 years.'
hint2: 'For a long time, my height mattered more for signals than for sight.'
hint2Explanation: The tower's height made it useful for radio and broadcast transmissions, which helped justify keeping it standing.'
hint3: 'Wind passes through me instead of pushing against me.'
hint3Explanation: 'Its open lattice design allows wind to pass through, reducing pressure and increasing stability.'
hint4: 'When I appeared in 1889, I was the tallest structure humans had ever made.'
hint4Explanation: 'At the time of its completion, it surpassed all previous man-made structures in height.'
hint5: 'I stand on the Champ de Mars in Paris.'
hint5Explanation: This precisely identifies the Eiffel Tower's location.'

solutionExplanation: 'The hints describe Venice, a car-free city defined by canals, bridges, Carnival traditions, and its unique location on a lagoon in northeastern Italy.'
hint1: 'For part of the year, faces disappear while the city fills up.'
hint1Explanation: During Venice's annual Carnival, many people wear traditional Venetian masks, hiding their faces. At the same time, the city fills with visitors from around the world.'
hint2: 'You can cross the entire city without ever seeing a car.'
hint2Explanation: 'Venice has no roads for cars. Movement happens on foot or by boat, making it possible to walk across the city without encountering any automobiles.'
hint3: 'Here, streets are wet and parking is mostly floating.'
hint3Explanation: 'Canals function as streets, and boats serve as the primary vehicles.'
hint4: 'This city was built across more than a hundred small islands.'
hint4Explanation: 'Venice is spread over 100+ islands connected by bridges.'
hint5: 'I lie in a lagoon on the Adriatic Sea, in northeastern Italy.'
hint5Explanation: This gives Venice's unique geographic setting.'

solutionExplanation: These clues describe the Mona Lisa, a small but famous painting known for its ambiguity, long visitor queues, and its place in the Louvre as Leonardo da Vinci's most renowned work.'
hint1: 'People line up patiently, only to spend a moment with me.'
hint1Explanation: 'Visitors often queue for long periods just to briefly view the painting.'
hint2: 'People are often surprised by how small I actually am.'
hint2Explanation: 'The Mona Lisa is much smaller than many expect after seeing reproductions.'
hint3: 'I am famous for what I do not clearly reveal.'
hint3Explanation: Her ambiguous expression and unclear smile are central to the painting's fame.'
hint4: 'I was painted in the early 16th century and now reside in the Louvre.'
hint4Explanation: 'Leonardo painted it around 1503�1506; it is displayed in Paris.'
hint5: I am Leonardo da Vinci's most famous painting.'

solutionExplanation: 'The clues lead to Alfred Nobel, whose invention of dynamite and concern over his legacy resulted in the Nobel Prizes that made him famous for honoring others.'
hint1: 'Nowadays, I am mostly famous for making other people famous.'
hint1Explanation: 'Nobel is best known for the prizes that honor others, not his own work.'
hint2: 'My invention meant for construction ended up shaping warfare.'
hint2Explanation: 'Dynamite was designed for mining and construction but became widely used in war.'
hint3: 'Seeing how I was described publicly changed how I thought about my legacy.'
hint3Explanation: 'A premature obituary called Nobel a �merchant of death,� reportedly influencing his decision to establish the prizes.'
hint4: 'I was a Swedish chemist and engineer active in the 19th century.'
hint5: 'I established the Nobel Prizes through my will.'
hint5Explanation: 'Nobel left his fortune to fund the prizes after his death.'

solutionExplanation: 'All hints point to a passport, a state-issued document that certifies nationality, records travel, and determines how freely someone can cross international borders.'
hint1: 'I am small, but I decide how far you can go.'
hint1Explanation: A passport's power determines where and how freely a person can travel.'
hint2: 'My pages tell a story mostly through marks, not sentences.'
hint2Explanation: 'Stamps, visas, and entry marks show travel history without needing narrative text.'
hint3: 'Some versions of me open far more doors than others.'
hint3Explanation: 'Different passports grant very different levels of visa-free access.'
hint4: 'I am issued by a state to certify nationality.'
hint4Explanation: A passport formally confirms the holder's nationality.'
hint5: 'I am required to cross most international borders.'
hint5Explanation: This defines the passport's core function.'
